prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Arp 220 H29alpha band 6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: image H29alpha line and continuum emision at 250 GHz from Arp 220 at a resolution of 0.18".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The line peak of 11 mJy/beam for H29alpha line is expected from H26alpha line flux detected from ALMA cycle 0 observations assuming that the hydrogen recombination lines at submm wavelengths are LTE and major fraction of the H29alpha line emission arises from the cental region which is partially resolved at a resolution of 0.18". For the weak line and strong continuum 0.1 Jy/beam at 256 GHz, a spectral dynamic range of 100:1 or better for bandpass calibration is required in order to produce reliable images for the distribution of the H29alpha line emission and the kinematics of the ionized disk in this source. The contiuum intensity is based on SMA observations at 230, 340 and 690 GHz.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Arp 220 H28alpha band 7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: image the H28alpha line and continuum emission at 285 GHz from Arp 220 at a resolution of 0.18"

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The line peak of 9 mJy/beam for H28alpha line is expected from H26alpha line flux detected from ALMA cycle 0 observations assuming that the hydrogen recombination lines at submm wavelengths are LTE and major fraction of the H28alpha line emission arises from the cental region which is partially resolved at a resolution of 0.15". For the weak line and strong continuum 0.11 Jy/beam at 284 GHz, a spectral dynamic range of 110:1 or better for bandpass calibration is required in order to produce reliable images for the distribution of the H28alpha line emission and the kinematics of the ionized disk in this source. The contiuum intensity is based on SMA observations at 230, 340 and 690 GHz.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Arp 220 H25alpha band 8
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: image the H25alpha line and continuum emission at 397 GHz

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The line peak of 12 mJy/beam for H25alpha line is expected from H26alpha line flux detected from ALMA cycle 0 observations assuming that the hydrogen recombination lines at submm wavelengths are LTE and major fraction of the H25alpha line emission arises from the cental region which is partially resolved at a resolution of 0.15". For the weak line and strong continuum 0.32 Jy/beam at 397 GHz, a spectral dynamic range of 233:1 or better for bandpass calibration is required in order to produce reliable images for the distribution of the H25alpha line emission and the kinematics of the ionized disk in this source. The contiuum intensity is based on SMA observations at 230, 340 and 690 GHz.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Arp 220 H21alpha band 9
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: image the H21alpha and 13CO(6-5) lines, and continuum emission at 662.4 GHz from Arp 220 at a resolution of 0.15".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The line peak of 20 mJy/beam for the H21alpha line is expected from H26alpha line flux detected from ALMA cycle 0 observations assuming that the hydrogen recombination lines at submm wavelengths are LTE and major fraction of the H21alpha line emission arises from the central region which is partially resolved at a resolution of 0.15". For the weak H26alpha line and strong continuum emission 1.7 Jy/beam at 660 GHz, a spectral dynamic range of 425:1 or better in bandpass calibration is required in order to produce reliable images for H21alpha line distribution and the kinematics of the ionized disk in this source. The continuum intensity is based on SMA observations at 230, 340 and 690.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC 4945 H21alpha band 9
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: image the H21alpha and 13CO(6-5)line, and continuum emission at 660 GHz from NGC 4945 at a resolution of 0.15".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The line peak of 79 mJy/beam for the H21alpha line is expected from the H36alpha line flux detected in the SEST observations assuming that the hydrogen recombination lines at mm-submm wavelengths are LTE and at least half of the line peak flux density arises from the central region which is partially resolved at a resolution of 0.15". The continuum peak of 3.2 Jy/beam at 662 GHz is estimated from the SMA observations at 230 GHz assuming a power-law spectrum with spectral index of 3 for the continuum emission. For the weak line, a spectraldynamic range of 400:1 is required in the bandpass calibration in order to produce reliable images for the H21alpha line distribution and kinematics of the ionized disk in this source.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC 4945 H25alpha band 8
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: image the H25alpha line and continuum emission at 397 Ghz from NGC 4945 at a angular resolution of 0.15".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The line peak of 47 mJy/beam for the H25alpha line is expected from the H36alpha line flux detected in the SEST observations assuming that the hydrogen recombination lines at mm-submm wavelengths are LTE and at least half of the line flux density arises from the central region which is partially resolved at a resolution of 0.15". The continuum emission peak of 0.59 Jy/beam at 397 GHz is estimated from the SMA observations at 230 GHz assuming a power-law spectrum with a spectral index of 3 for the continuum emission. For the weak line and strong continuum emission, a spectral dynamic range of 118:1 is required in bandpass calibration in order to produce reliable images for the H25 alpha line distribution and kinematics of the ionized disk in this source.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC 4945 H28alpha band 7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: image the H28alpha line and continuum emission at 284 GHz from NGC 4945 at a resolution of 0.15".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The line peak of 34 mJy/beam for H28alpha line is expected from the H36alpha line flux detected in the SEST observations assuming that the hydrogen recombination lines at mm-submm wavelengths are LTE and at least half of the line peak flux density arises from the central region which is partially resolved at a resolution of 0.15". The continuum emission peak 0.19 Jy/beam at 284 GHz is estimated from the SMA observations at 230 GHz assuming a power-law spectrum with spectral index of 3 for the continuum emission. A spectral dynamic range of 48:1 is required.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC 4945 H29alpha band 6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: image the H29alpha line and continuum emission at 256 GHz from NGC 4945 at a resolution of 0.18".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The line peak of 44 mJy/beam for the H29alpha line is expected from the H36alpha line flux detected in the SEST observations assuming that the hydrogen recombination lines at mm-submm wavelengths are LTE and at least half of the line flux density arises from the central region which is partially resolved at a resolution of 0.18". The continuum emssion peak of 0.18 Jy/beam is estimated from the SMA observations assuming a power-law spectrum with spectral index of 3 for the continuum emission. A spectral dynamic range of 45:1 is needed for imaging the line distribution and kinematics of the ionized disk in this source.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose ALMA to observed the RRLs H29a, H28a, H25a & H21a at submm wavelengths from Arp 220 and NGC 4945 that host both starburst and AGN activities in the extreme nuclear environments of ULIRGs. The low-N transition (hydrogen) RRLs originate from the UC/HC HII regions that are produced from the very recent starburst episodes in the nuclei. Constrained by the RRLS flux observed with ALMA and with AT, VLA, IRAM 30m and SEST at cm-mm wavelengths, we will model the ionized regions providing sensible parameters for ionized mass content, total Lyman continuum flux, the total number of OB stars and the SFRs for the high-mass stars over the period of multiple starburst episods.The kinematics determined from the ALMA observations of RRLs will be used to understand the feedback from the nuclear activities (starburst and AGNs) and the fate of the ionized gas. As a useful by-product, we will observe 13CO(6-5) line for the content of molecular gas that is associated with the dense protostellar cores; the kinematics observed from the relatively optically-thin molecular species also provide data in understanding how the molecular gas fuels to the starburst and AGN activities.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Domenici Science Operations Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
